Dear Melynda Williams:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a corrective action plan is required. The corrective action
plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter, must be completed and routed in CWLM,
and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126 Staff sufficiency
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of
Description administrative, supervisory, social service, direct care, and
other staff on duty to perform the prescribed functions
required by these administrative rules and in the agency's
1

program statement and to provide for the continual needs,
protection, and supervision of residents
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff fell asleep at the McLaren Hospital while supervising Youth
A.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant 1 was emailed on 3/17/25. She reported she
received the allegations from hospital staff. Names of the hospital
staff were provided and noted as the following complainants.
Complainant 2, Complainant 3, and Complainant 4 were
emailed on 3/17/25. Complainant 2 responded on 3/25/25. He
reported in a group email, they did not see the agency staff
sleeping while they supervised Youth A, but did have a picture
that was given to them by a hospital staff. Complainant 2 reported
he had sent the photograph to Administrator 1.
On 3/19/25, I interviewed Administrator 1. Administrator 1
reported she was aware of the allegations and in fact were in the
process of providing Staff 1 and Staff 2 disciplinary action for their
actions at the hospital.
On 3/28/25, I interviewed Staff 1 via telephone. Staff 1 reported
she supervised Youth A at the Mclaren hospital and did fall asleep
when there.
On 3/28/25, I interviewed Staff 2 via telephone. Staff 2 reported
she did not fall asleep at the hospital and refused to sign her
written disciplinary action.
On 4/1/25, Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility and
refused to talk to me about the hospital.
Documents Reviewed:
• On 3/28/25 Administrator 1 sent me the picture of Staff 1
sleeping in a chair at the hospital. Staff 1 had a blanket
around her and her eyes closed.
• Progressive Notification Form (2). Staff 1 and Staff 2 both
received disciplinary points for sleeping at the hospital
while supervising Youth A. The documents noted Staff 1 fell
asleep on 3/12/25 and Staff 2 was noted to fall asleep on
2

3/11/25. It is noted that Staff 2 refused to sign the
disciplinary action.
• I reviewed the agency’s “Children Supervision Policy.”
Residential staff are expected to maintain and document
direct visual contact of children they will be supervising.
Staff are always to remain “awake” and “alert.”
• I reviewed both Staff 1 and Staff 2 personnel files. Both
staff had up to date central registry and both had sufficient
training in accordance with licensing rules. Both staff
received “Off Grounds Training” due to this incident on
3/22/25.
Analysis The agency is noncompliant with this rule. Staff 1 did not provide
for the supervision of the child at the hospital. Staff 1 admitted to
sleeping at the hospital and the photograph provided by
Complainant 2 supported this. There is no evidence to validate
Staff 2 was asleep at the hospital. The “Children’s Supervision
Policy” states staff are to be awake and alert during their
supervision of children.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
